title: Victoria says loot boxes are gambling

embed.description: The state of Victoria has joined the throng of governments who have voiced concern about the practices of loot boxes in games. Belgium and Hawaii have both come out against loot boxes today and now the state of Victoria has joined the ranks.

replies.body:
the thing is its worse than just "gambling". generally when gambling you are given odds on your money and generally you can do some maths to know percentages even in sports. so unless there is some kind of match fixing taking place or a machine is tampered with, it is "fair". it is "real".

with riot and most other gaming companies, absolutely no odds or percentages are given, there is no real math behind it either. riot can literally rig the boxes and chop and change the numbers whenever they want. no doubt your spending habits are being taken into account (don't you think its 'strange" that early on people get "good" skins). they could even make some accounts be "luckier" than others (cough pearl abyss' black desert online cough). . and it is perfectly legal for them to do so at the moment.

>or a machine is tampered with

Which their are laws against if you get caught doing shit like this, and a lot of machines that are possible to tamper with are checked daily.
and when they ban Loot boxes from OCE and not the rest of the world instead of saying "ha got you Riot" people will simply be whinging they can get get loot boxes...

also an interesting fact is very recently (sept 13) the Interactive Gambling Amendment Act 2017 ( https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2017A00085 ) came into play. essentially online, "interactive gambling" is banned in Australia. eg i can no longer play poker online like i used to. this excludes "betting services".

>  This Act imposes the following prohibitions:
> 
>        (a)     a prohibited interactive gambling service must not be provided to customers in Australia;
> 
>       (b)     unlicensed regulated interactive gambling services must not be provided to customers in Australia;
> 
>        (c)     an Australian‑based prohibited interactive gambling service must not be provided to customers in designated countries;
> 
>       (d)     prohibited interactive gambling services must not be advertised;
> 
>        (e)     unlicensed regulated interactive gambling services must not be advertised.
> 
> •      The ACMA may, on its own initiative, or in response to a complaint, investigate whether a person has contravened a provision of this Act that imposes any of those prohibitions.
> 
> •      A body or association that represents internet service providers may develop an industry code.
> 
> •      The ACMA has a reserve power to make an industry standard if there is no industry code or if an industry code is deficient.
> 
> •      The ACMA must notify prohibited internet gambling content to internet service providers so that the providers can deal with the content in accordance with procedures specified in an industry code or industry standard.

riot and others are on thin ice here. once the law catches up with gaming companies, surely this will be considered "interactive gambling" and will be prohibited.
